text: What sports? I’m sceptical it would work for anything other than horse racing

elements.text: What sports? I’m sceptical it would work for anything other than horse racing

text: Sorry to jump on this question, but i'm curious what makes it work for horse racing and not other sports?

elements.text: Sorry to jump on this question, but i'm curious what makes it work for horse racing and not other sports?

text:
Only considering pre-event:

I don't really know much about horse racing markets but from what I've heard people say, there is often a lot of price action with nothing fundamental behind it. Under these circumstances, it makes sense that you could take some kind of typical financial modelling approach of treating the price evolution as a random walk and trading a mean reversion strategy by continually backing above and laying below a central price.

It feels like other sports are much more fundamental driven - e.g. a star player is injured in training or an updated weather forecast comes in that produces a step change in the price. I would imagine you'd get killed when this happens as you'd be completely taken out at the wrong price, wiping out any profits that you'd pick up from the mean reversion.

elements.text:

It feels like other sports are much more fundamental driven - e.g. a star player is injured in training or an updated weather forecast comes in that produces a step change in the price. I would imagine you'd get killed when this happens as you'd be completely taken out at the wrong price, wiping out any profits that you'd pick up from the mean reversion.

text: Yes there are some insane moves on the pre-off horses for no apparent reason at all. Really not unusual to see a runner start at 3.0 drift out to 5.0 then back again in the 10 mins prior to off. Of course sometimes there are things that make it move like a runner playing up when handlers are trying to get it in the stalls etc but a lot of the time there is no obvious reason for moves. <@UKD8R5P9N> when you say probability based tick movement what kind of scale are you talking about? You looking to model probability of price moving +/- X ticks from current based on prior time series?

elements.text: Yes there are some insane moves on the pre-off horses for no apparent reason at all. when you say probability based tick movement what kind of scale are you talking about? You looking to model probability of price moving +/- X ticks from current based on prior time series?

text: I have personally tried to automate trading off some traditional financial indicators. I tried MACD, RSI and bollinger bands with various adaptations without any success at all. Can't say I am that surprised in hindsight but it was one of the first things I investigated when I had gathered a decent size collection of market data.

elements.text: I have personally tried to automate trading off some traditional financial indicators. I tried MACD, RSI and bollinger bands with various adaptations without any success at all. Can't say I am that surprised in hindsight but it was one of the first things I investigated when I had gathered a decent size collection of market data.

text:
:+1: to what Mo said at the beginning I think. 

But I think simply relying on the principle of “mean reversion” across the board probably isn’t enough to become profitable. The racing markets are more efficient than that. In my experience you need at least another small edge to judge where the price is likely to tend (eg. Liam mentioned WOM, but that doesn’t work anymore of course). Or alternatively you need to be more selective on which markets are more likely to mean revert. I suppose ideally the former encapsulates the latter so you don’t need to worry about the latter.

elements.text:

Or alternatively you need to be more selective on which markets are more likely to mean revert. I suppose ideally the former encapsulates the latter so you don’t need to worry about the latter.

text: I'll add with racing, adding in form/fundamental data certainly helps. You can identify profiles of horses that the market likes to oppose/support.

elements.text: I'll add with racing, adding in form/fundamental data certainly helps. You can identify profiles of horses that the market likes to oppose/support.

text: We hear that racing BF starting prices are efficient overall, but there is no way on earth that the market is efficient at every point in time up to the race start. Some of the price action is crazy - no way at all that the actual probability of a runner winning can change over the last 10 minutes before the start unless there is noticable changes in body language.

elements.text: We hear that racing BF starting prices are efficient overall, but there is no way on earth that the market is efficient at every point in time up to the race start. Some of the price action is crazy - no way at all that the actual probability of a runner winning can change over the last 10 minutes before the start unless there is noticable changes in body language.

text: I'll also add that I am only trading AU racing where price action is largely controlled by 2 syndicates, so it is not overly hard to reverse engineer the type of horses they like to back

elements.text: I'll also add that I am only trading AU racing where price action is largely controlled by 2 syndicates, so it is not overly hard to reverse engineer the type of horses they like to back

text: <@UNQGKT0CR> I don’t think so

elements.text: I don’t think so

text: If you had a half decent pricing model for the horses, asssuming that final BFSP is indeed efficient you could make a killing value betting alone. The price fluctuations would give you a decent window of opportunity if you had something moderately accurate. I tried myself years ago scraping RP website to get a database going with the view to doing a multinomial logistic regression on it but I found too many errors in the data. Might be easier these days with something like proform but I suspect that it would still be very very hard as there is a lot of "inside" info which probably has far more impact than the publicly available data.

elements.text: If you had a half decent pricing model for the horses, asssuming that final BFSP is indeed efficient you could make a killing value betting alone. text: <@UUE6E1LA1> That’s true, but at the same time the market sort of is efficient if you can’t predict where the price will move without looking retrospectively. Of course some people can, so it’s not 100% efficient, but it’s harder to do than it seems when people say the price can’t be 3.0 and 5.0 at the same time. It can’t, but how do you know which it is!

Not sure why people think BSP is efficient, all you are seeing is the law of large of numbers as you can almost take the market at any time and it’s just as accurate. I make money off BSP in racing and got banned from betdaq’s XSP last year. 

There are quite a few using timeform data with ML and making a killing.
